children: A 50-year-old man is evaluated for a slowly evolving lesion on the dorsal aspect of the left arm.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma. As in this case, cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma presents as a slowly evolving, isolated keratotic or eroded macule, papule, or nodule that commonly appears on the sun-exposed skin, including the face, scalp, neck, pinna, lip, or extremities. In contrast, a basal cell carcinoma most commonly demonstrates a heaped-up waxy or pearly border, whereas a keratoacanthoma usually presents as a rapidly growing nodule with a central area of keratinized material.
